The impact of the Covid-19 Pandemic has been unprecedented and countries are still struggling to get back to their old normal. People have stayed indoors for months in a row. Even developed nations are reeling under the pressure of a weak economy. It is tough to say how long the coronavirus will continue to play havoc. Now, many nations have started to relax the stay-at-home restrictions and allowed some selective categories of businesses to open in a phased manner. As people, food premises, and workplaces are trying to resume their businesses, it is crucial to follow the precautionary measures for protection against Covid-19.

Whether you run a commercial kitchen or have a workplace, you should keep all the cleaning of Your Workplaces and surfaces clean. There are disinfectants and sanitizers that you can use to enhance protection against Covid-19.

 

Free Quote (800-750-7055)

 

Cleaning Food Premises

Covid-19 has created a risky situation for every restaurant, food premise or food store. As food establishments start to reopen, owners should pay serious attention to the cleanliness and hygiene for the safety of the staff and guests. If guests and workers don’t feel safe under the current pandemic, they won’t come and your restaurant business will suffer as a result. Local authorities too will require you to follow some safety guidelines as long as Covid-19 risk looms.

The United States Food & Drug Administration has shared guidelines in this regard for food stores and food establishments to follow. From the kitchen hood system, cooking utensils, food prep surfaces and ovens to refrigerators and the walls and floors, the food establishment owners are responsible for managing the cleaning, sanitizing and disinfecting of the entire restaurant to ensure better safety and health of the employees and the guests. Each area of a commercial kitchen requires a different approach for cleaning and sanitization. If you lack expert knowledge about kitchen cleaning, you should hire a professional company.

It’s not that cleaning and disinfecting are new practices. Food premises and commercial kitchens have long been abiding by the cleanliness and good hygiene for the health and safety of workers and customers. But the current pandemic has put cleaning, sanitizing and disinfecting under great focus. All restaurants, that are now reopening, are required to strictly take cleanliness measures.

Restaurants and food premises need to focus on the following:

Practice Hand Hygiene:

If you run a food store, hand hygiene is the first important thing to follow. Whether it is your employees or the customers that visit your establishment, you should make sure they wash their hands frequently to reduce the risk of coronavirus infection. If soap and water are not available, provide them with alcohol-based hand sanitizers. Kitchen workers, who have greasy or dirty hands, should first remember to clean their hands and then use hand sanitizers. Otherwise, using hand sanitizers will not be useful.

Clean Surfaces and Equipment:

Keep a close watch on the surfaces and don’t let dust gather anywhere. Dirty surfaces make it easy for harmful bacteria and germs to grow. By cleaning the surfaces on a regular basis, you can immediately reduce the chances of breeding of pathogens. Whether it’s cooking surfaces, cooking utensils, commercial kitchen walls, grills, kitchen hoods, sinks or the oven, you should make sure that all the surfaces and equipment are cleaned frequently. In any case, don’t forget to clean the glasswasher and the dishwasher.

Sanitize Surfaces:

Sanitization is a process through which you can eradicate the pathogens or bring the number of harmful germs down to a level that is considered to be safe. There is a large variety of chemicals and products that you can use to sanitize the food contact surfaces. It is important to use sanitizers on all kitchen hoods, sinks, faucets, coffee machines etc. The cooking utensils and kitchen walls, as well as kitchen floors, should be sanitized as well. Always remember to use a strong sanitizer and leave it for enough time for proper sanitization.

Disinfect High Touch Surfaces:

Disinfectants are used to kill pathogens. You should apply disinfectant to frequently touched surfaces in your food premise. This should be done in addition to cleaning of surfaces. In this way, you can bring down the risk of spreading the infection to a great extent.

Cleaning and sanitizing have been in practice by foodservice operations. Covid-19 has taken this one step ahead to disinfecting. Now, all food stores and food premises need to pay more attention to disinfecting, which means killing harmful germs, bacteria, and pathogens on surfaces. So, while you should regularly clean the food contact surfaces and sanitize surfaces, you should never forget to use disinfectants to further enhance the safety of your kitchen staff and guests.

There is plenty to sanitize and disinfect inside a commercial restaurant. Whether it is the restaurant tables, food preparation surfaces or the kitchen equipment, you’ll need to keep all these free from pathogens. There are special sanitizers for each of these items and surfaces. For example, sanitizing rinses are available for dishes and cooking utensils in a kitchen. Likewise, there are sanitizers for the sanitization of cooking surfaces inside a commercial kitchen.

A commercial kitchen is a pretty big place with lots of areas, surfaces and items that need cleaning, sanitizing, and disinfecting. It is a good idea to create a checklist of all the items and decide a specific frequency for cleaning them. For example, items such as the grill, range, griddle, flattops, coffee makers, prep area surfaces, beverage dispenser heads need more frequent cleaning and disinfecting. Waste disposal areas and trash cans also need disinfecting on a daily basis. There are other items or areas that can be cleaned and disinfected on a weekly or monthly basis. These include deep fryers, walk-in refrigerator, ice machine, vent hoods, etc.

Cleaning and disinfecting the kitchen floor is an important task. Though it sounds like a simple task, it is actually a complex one. The floor gathers plenty of grease over time, which is a safety hazard. A traditional bucket and mop will not remove this grease buildup from the floor.

Cleaning a greasy floor requires the use of the right type of chemicals and the right approach and technique. Give HoodBuilder a quick call to schedule a consultation for proper cleaning of your kitchen floor.

 

Free Quote (800-750-7055)

Cleaning Your Workplace

Offices, government buildings, and reception areas need proper and thorough cleaning on a regular basis to reduce the spread of Covid-19. Even if you have an office or workplace in an area where there is no community spread of Covid-19, you should take all the precautionary measures.

General Cleaning:

Just because you have sanitizers and disinfectants, it doesn’t mean cleaning is not important. In fact, cleaning is essential as it eliminates dust and dirt from surfaces. If dirt and organic matter stay on surfaces, they can make it easy for harmful bacteria and germs to breed. Even when you want to disinfect a surface, you should first clean that surface.

Disinfection:

After a surface has been cleaned, it may still have pathogens. Cleaning only reduces pathogens, it doesn’t kill them. On the other hand, disinfectants kill germs and pathogens that remain after cleaning. Therefore, using disinfectant is a surefire way of reducing the risks of infection.

Routine Cleaning:

A workplace can be big or small. It can be used by a number of people or a few people. Depending on the amount of traffic in the workplace, you should decide the frequency of cleaning. Those areas that are frequently accessed by the public should be cleaned more frequently. You should keep an eye out for dust or dirt anywhere in the workplace and make sure that you get it cleaned as soon as you spot it. During the Covid-19 pandemic, it is crucial to be extremely careful in regard to the cleaning of all areas in the workplace.

Workplaces tend to get cluttered very often. To keep the entire workplace in good order and create a healthy environment, you should declutter in an effective manner. This is also important because a decluttered workplace is easier to clean. Whether it is the desks, keyboards or telephones, each essential item in the workplace needs cleaning on a regular basis. In a workplace, all the frequently touched areas need cleaning, sanitizing and disinfecting on a regular basis.

In the workplace, you need to create awareness around Covid-19 and how everyone can help prevent the spread of coronavirus. You should place sanitizing hand rub dispensers throughout the workplace so that employees and visitors can easily access them to sanitize their hands. Hand washing should be promoted through banners and posters. At the same time, make hand washing easy for employees and visitors. Using soap and water is best for washing hands. Washing hands frequently prevents the spread of the Covid-19 infection.

How to Clean and Disinfect

For Covid-19 related cleaning and disinfecting, there are some guidelines that should be followed. Cleaners should wear gloves before getting started with the process. There are reusable gloves that can be used for this purpose. After the task is complete, the gloves can be removed, cleaned, and dried.

The process begins with cleaning. Use a detergent solution to properly clean all the areas and surfaces in the food premise, kitchen, or workplace. After the surfaces have been cleaned, it is time for the application of disinfectants. Use a paper towel or a disposable cloth to apply the chemical to surfaces. Always ensure you use high-quality products and follow the manufacturer’s guidelines. Pay attention to the ‘contact time’ when you apply disinfectant to a surface. You need to leave the chemical on the surface for some time so as to kill the viruses.

Safety is important even when cleaning the different areas of a workplace or a food establishment. While cleaning is going on, the cleaning people should avoid touching their eyes, nose and mouth. For greater protection, surgical masks can also be used. The cleaning staff should also sanitize their hands before wearing and after removing hand gloves.

 

Free Quote (800-750-7055)

 

Choosing the Disinfectant Solution

Whether it is a commercial kitchen or an office, cleaners should always use high-quality disinfectant solutions. There are different types of disinfectants including chlorine dioxide, sodium hypochlorite, hydrogen peroxide, quaternary ammonia, Audobon disinfectant etc. Chlorine-based disinfectants or those with 70% alcohol have anti-viral properties. So, it is important to find out whether the disinfectant solution you are using is formulated for anti-viral activity.

Using household bleach is another option. This disinfectant solution is available in a variety of strengths. You can read the details about the solution to the product label. Quaternary ammonium compounds are also a good alternative for a disinfectant solution. In fact, these chemicals are known to combine two properties into one - detergent and disinfection property.

Image Source Food trucks have come a long way from the early days of mobile dining. Today, people derive as much joy eating from a food truck as dining at a brick and mortar restaurant. From sandwiches and hamburgers to cupcakes and hybrid taco-waffles, food trucks offer a wide range of delectable menu items.  But when exactly did mobile dining begin? Who invented the idea of selling food from a food truck? Let us dig into the past.

Chuck Wagon - The Original Food Truck

Chuckwagons are a direct ancestor of the modern-day food truck. Long back in 1866, there lived a rancher in Texas, named Charles Goodnight. The idea of the chuck wagon struck Goodnight’s mind when he felt the need to feed cattlemen going on long cattle drives. So, he got a surplus US Army wagon and turned it into what we now call a food truck. Goodnight attached a chuck box to the back of the wagon to make it easy to cook and prepare food, hence the name. Goodnight modified the chuck wagon and designed multiple portions in it to cook food, store supplies, keep a water barrel etc.  Initially, the use of chuck wagons was limited to the cattle industry. Over time, the idea of mobile dining picked up steam and the role of chuck wagons expanded to serve the eating needs of other industries and classes. Common food items sold through chuck wagons included salted meat, beans, coffee, biscuits etc. Goodnight’s portable kitchen went on to make a lasting impact.

Pushcarts - Another Predecessor of the Food Truck

Yet another ancestor of the modern-day food truck is pushcarts. In fact, the history of pushcarts is older than that of chuck wagons. When Dutch immigrants arrived in New York city, they looked for ways to make some money. They started the use of food carts to sell food. New York city and Chicago were places where these push carts were more common to see. In 1691, laws were also formulated to control the selling of food by these mobile food vendors. Pushcarts mainly served the eating needs of the urban working class, specially those who were looking for inexpensive meals.  The early pushcarts did not cook or prepare food on-site. They only sold food items that were ready to eat. Modern Food Trucks Chuck wagons have almost disappeared from the mobile food vending scene today. They are no longer used to cook food. However, you’ll definitely see different variations of the pushcart in many US cities. Refrigerated ice cream trucks, which came up in the 1950s, became another inspiration for food vendors. The number of food trucks increased across the cities of the United States. Construction workers formed a strong customer base for mobile food vendors around the 1960s.  Today, the moment we hear the word ‘food truck’, delicacies such as fish tacos, pork sandwiches and home-cooked Mediterranean food start to make our mouths water. The shape and design of food trucks have undergone a revolution. They have now become so ubiquitous and serve food items to all classes including working professionals as well as the younger generation. Food trucks don’t just offer variety in terms of food items, but they also cater to every budget. Modern-day food trucks are not like the ‘roach coaches’ of the early years. They follow the highest standards of cleanliness to ensure the health and safety of all customers.  Food trucks continue to get better. Many of them have also adopted new technologies to simplify business management. Customers can now pay and avail themselves of loyalty programs via street food apps.

Abbreviated as HVAC, the heating ventilation and air conditioning is a common, daily use system, which provides heating and cooling. Generally, people use the term HVAC to refer to this system. The system remains installed in a wide range of residential as well as commercial buildings. Right from the time HVAC systems were first introduced, their popularity has been on the rise continuously. This is due to their customizable design and optimum levels of comfort they offer. The main reason for the installation of the HVAC systems is that they provide warmth during the winters and coolness and freshness during summers. But these systems do a lot more than that. The HVAC also improves the air quality inside homes, offices, and buildings through filtering and maintaining the humidity level to provide a healthy and comfortable environment. At Hood Builder, we specialize in the design, installation, maintenance, and repair of different types of HVAC systems for restaurants. For your knowledge, we have prepared this guide, which includes information on how HVAC systems function, HVAC history, types of HVAC systems, and HVAC design as well as their installation and maintenance. So, let us dive in!

How Do HVAC Systems Work?

Though the designs of HVAC systems vary, the basic components in all of the systems are the same. Just as the acronym suggests, the system performs three key functions - heating, ventilation, and air conditioning. This is the reason why these systems have a comprehensive design.  If the HVAC system stops working in your restaurant or building, you will know instantly. One of the most important functions of this system is ventilation or mechanical ventilation to be more precise. For a comfortable environment inside a commercial restaurant, apartment, or building, the exchange of air should never stop. The V in HVAC does exactly that. It moves the air inside and outside. Not only that, once the air has been drawn in, the system filters the air to make it free from dust, dirt, and allergens and provides clean and fresh air. Once the quality of the indoor air has improved, the system will send it either for heating or cooling. Plus, the HVAC system will also keep the humidity in the air at an optimum level. After the air quality has been improved, the system will then direct the fresh and clean air into the home or facility.

The History of HVAC

Today, we can install and use HVAC systems for comfortable living or working. But it was not like this always. Before the first version of these systems came into being, people were used to steamy summers and chilly winters. The concept for a centralized HVAC took birth in the mid-1800s. Digging into the ancient history of Egyptians, Greeks, Romans, and Chinese tell us that the very early concept of the HVAC is not new. Though these people did not actually come up with a system, they did use some techniques to keep the air cool or warm. For example, the Egyptians hung reeds in windows to make the air cool in a natural way. Later, the Greeks and Romans invented the idea of using aqueducts. This is from where the cooling and heating water pipe systems in cities were inspired. The Chinese gave the fan to the world. In the Victorian era, various aspects of unique architecture were developed for cross-ventilation.

The 1800s:

The credit for developing the modern HVAC system goes to Dr. John Gorrie. First, he put forward the idea of keeping cities cool during the summer months. Then, he designed a system to perform this specific function. With the use of cooling coils, he succeeded in bringing humidity levels under control. After getting the device patented, he further worked on finetune the system to create an automatic humidity and temperature-controlled system. 

The 1900s:

Dr. John’s idea continued to improve in the decades that followed. In 1904, a refrigeration system was developed and used to cool the entire Missouri State Building. After this, the cooling and heating systems were installed in public theatres. This was a remarkable development.

Modern HVAC:

While HVAC systems were used by commercial buildings, homeowners found it out of their budget. In 1932, H.H. Schultz and J.Q. Sherman designed an affordable unit for use in homes. The new HVAC unit was less expensive and could easily fit in window sills. After this development, the use of HVAC systems expanded in homes and apartments. By the 1960s, most homes were using at least some form of HVAC with central air conditioning. Today, we have the most advanced versions of the early heating and cooling systems. The best part is that today’s HVAC can be installed in a way that it remains hidden while offering completely soundless heating and cooling. All you need to do is switch a button and the entire system starts to work.

Types of HVAC Systems

HVAC systems have a complicated design. In fact, it is available in so many different types that choosing the right one for your restaurant or commercial building can prove to be quite daunting. Given below are some of the most common types of commercial HVAC systems you will come across.

Split HVAC System:

The system is so named because of the way it is installed in a commercial building. Key parts of this HVAC include air handler (indoor unit), condenser (outdoor unit), thermostat, filtration system, and ductwork. Each of these components performs a specific and important role.  The Split HVAC System can be further categorized into Single-Split and Multi-Split. The Single Split HVAC is a good match for small commercial spaces such as cafes, shops and offices. The Multi-Split HVAC is designed and installed in a way that keeps all the indoor units connected to one external unit. This type of HVAC is ideal for large commercial spaces such as restaurants, large kitchens, retail shops, etc. The Multi-Split System needs to be installed by professionals because the HVAC design involves a lot of pipework and correct installation. If you want to have your restaurant fitted with a Split HVAC System, feel free to reach out to Hood Builders in Denver, CO. We offer professional HVAC installation for a wide range of hospitality businesses.

VR or VRF System:

The Variable Refrigerant Volume (VRV) or Variable Refrigerant Flow (VRF) system is different in terms of the heating and cooling element it uses in its design. This type of HVAC uses a refrigerant and is perfect for a range of medium and large commercial spaces. The VRV system can be further categorized into Heat Pump Systems and Heat Recovery Systems. The VR or VRF HVAC costs more than the Split HVAC. But the installation of the system is easy and quick. If the buildings have occupants, they can be set up without causing them any inconvenience. 

CAV and VAV Systems:

These are two different types of HVAC systems. A Constant Air Volume (CAV) system uses a compressor to bring the temperature in a building to the desired level. If you operate a commercial establishment where you need constant ventilation for a long period, this HVAC system is the most suitable. The Variable Air Volume (VAV) HVAC uses a compressor for ventilation as well as to regulate the flow of the refrigerant to achieve the desired temperature level. This type of HVAC is ideal for buildings where the needs for heating and cooling are very consistent. It offers high-quality control for humidity and temperature. The right type of HVAC for your restaurant, retail shop, or commercial building depends on what exactly your air conditioning needs. HVAC Repair

If the HVAC system fails to do its job effectively or it stops functioning altogether, you are going to need a repair service. The repairs needed to restore your HVAC system can be minor or costly. It is only after a close inspection that the technician will be able to identify the exact problem in the system and then suggest the ideal solution. If you are experiencing problems with your HVAC system, reach out to Hood Builder for the necessary repair works. Our technicians will find the problem swiftly and suggest the most ideal solution.

HVAC Design

The role of an HVAC design engineer is to build refrigeration and heating systems for commercial and residential buildings.  To design a highly efficient HVAC system, the engineer takes a number of critical factors into account. These include heat loss, heat gain, site orientation, air infiltration, etc. The professional apply various principles of thermodynamics and fluid mechanics to create and develop a top-quality system. A lot of research thought and planning goes into the building of the perfect HVAC design for a facility or building. The refrigerant, a chemical compound, plays a crucial role in the efficient operation of an HVAC system. You might have heard technicians often say: “Your HVAC needs a refrigerant recharge?” An air-conditioner has a non-flammable gas inside the copper coils. This is the refrigerant, which absorbs heat from the inside air of a commercial kitchen, restaurant, and other facilities that have HVAC systems installed. As the heat absorption begins, the low-pressure gas turns into a high-pressure liquid as it travels through compressors and evaporators. After its job is done, the liquid gets back to its gaseous form once again. It is important to understand the role of HVAC refrigerant as well as the necessity to get the recharge to avoid other issues.  

Free Quote (800-750-7055)

 

The Role of HVAC Refrigerant

The HVAC system for its functioning relies on refrigerant. In fact, the entire cooling process revolves around this chemical. The role of refrigerant is to first go through evaporation and then condensation. First, the compressor takes the refrigerant to a high-pressure point. As a result of this raised pressure, the chemical compound condenses and releases heat outdoors. After this, the compound evaporates to absorb heat and then deposit it outdoors. New technologies have emerged to make this entire procedure much more efficient than ever before to deliver highly effective cooling results. If the HVAC system in your facility doesn’t have the right amount of refrigerant, the AC will fail to effectively cool the property. So, it is important to keep the refrigerant level at a fixed amount at all times.

Types of Refrigerant Used in Air Conditioners

Not one type of refrigerant is used in all air conditioners. There are multiple types of refrigerants out there. The type of refrigerant you should use depends on the type or model of HVAC system you have installed. Many new refrigerants have replaced old types of refrigerants as well.

Some common refrigerants are as follows:

  • Chlorofluorocarbons
  • R22
  • R410
It is never a good idea to replace one type of refrigerant with another. Recharging your HVAC unit with the wrong chemical compound can cause damage to the entire system. Since it is not possible to interchange refrigerants, you should always pay attention to the type of refrigerant you need. An easy way to find the type of refrigerant your HVAC system uses is to read the large sticker on the compressor or the evaporator of the unit. Each refrigerant has its own specific benefits and unique features in terms of efficiency, air quality, comfort, etc.

Signs Your HVAC Needs a Refrigerant Recharge

The refrigerant is not there to be consumed by the system. In fact, the HVAC unit keeps on cycling the same quantity of refrigerant for an unlimited period of time - until the entire system breaks down. However, a recharge will be required in the event of a leak. If the HVAC technicians say your heating and cooling unit needs a refrigerant recharge, this is a major sign that there is an issue with the system. That is why the technician will first identify the location of the leak, repair it properly and then go ahead with recharging the chemical so that it doesn’t leak again. To find out whether it is time for a recharge, you should keep an eye on the warning signs.

Signs your HVAC needs a recharge to include:

  • The AC doesn’t cool the facility properly
  • Vent hoods are blowing warm air
  • Energy bills have gone up
  • The refrigerant line has ice deposits
  • The refrigerant lines make a hissing sound
If you are running a restaurant, commercial kitchen, cafeteria, or another facility, you should always pay serious attention to the performance of the HVAC system. As soon as you spot any issues or signs, you should seek the help of a professional agency such as Hood Builder in Denver, Colorado. Our company specializes in the installation, repair, and maintenance of a wide range of HVAC systems to help businesses have a smooth and hassle-free operation. There are multiple reasons your HVAC refrigerant can call for a recharge. If there is a leak, it could be due to the inefficiency of one of the components of the compressor. The system may have other issues which can cause the refrigerant to leak and not function in an effective manner.

What You Should Do

If you think refrigerant is leaking, you should never try to fix the problem yourself. It is the job of experts, and you should reach out to professionals for immediate help and solution to the problem.

Before HVAC technicians arrive, you should:

  • Switch off the air conditioner
  • Turn the thermostat fan on for 2-3 hours
  • Get in touch with technicians
All refrigerant issues must be handled by only certified professionals. Not only is fixing the problem on your own risky, but it is also against the safety laws and regulations. Whether it is a leak repair, removal of old refrigerant, or recharging with new refrigerant, all of these must be carried out by an expert, who is qualified and certified to do the job in accordance with the law. Licensed and trained HVAC technicians will quickly identify the exact problem with the HVAC refrigerant. They will fix the problem correctly, replace the refrigerant safely and handle the equipment in a risk-free manner and restore the right level of refrigerant.

Main Causes of Restaurant Fires

Cooking Equipment

Too much heat and moisture in a commercial kitchen can lead to multiple problems beyond discomfort. If your kitchen generates an excessive amount of heat, it will remain extremely hot and steamy even during the winter season. If you operate a restaurant, it is your utmost duty to keep both heat and moisture under control to avoid a wide range of problems. Doing this means customers will not choose another restaurant over yours and your employees will be happy. That is exactly why you should take all the essential steps required to run your commercial kitchen in a proper manner and keep customers coming in large numbers.

In this article, we will talk about how enormous heat and moisture can hurt your restaurant and your business bottom line as a result. Plus, we will discuss the use of Type II Condensate Hood, which is an ideal solution to the problem and how its installation will keep the kitchen cool.

How Uncontrolled Temperature Hurts Your Restaurant

The working environment inside a commercial kitchen is very fast-paced. Whether it is the chefs, assistants or the staff, it is a challenge for everyone to perform their role in a safe and comfortable manner.

While kitchen workers already have to perform their duties without any delay, a hot and humid environment puts extra strain on them. Elevated temperature or too much heat makes it really hard for employees to work. Such an uncontrolled, high-temperature environment takes a toll on the ability of kitchen workers. As a result of this, the workers face a number of comfort and health issues. Not only workers, but a great deal of heat in the kitchen also affects the entire restaurant. Customers are discouraged from visiting your restaurant due to poor temperature control. Diners always look for a cool and comfortable place to eat. If you plan for your business to attract more and more customers and grow, you should never ignore the kind of environment you provide to customers in your commercial restaurant. 

Excessive heat and humidity often leads to a condition called heat stress in employees affecting them in several ways such as:

  • Difficulty to concentrate
  • Muscle cramps
  • Heat rashes
  • Acute feeling of thirst
  • Fainting
  • Fatigue, nausea, vomiting
  • Headache
  • Heat stroke

Being a responsible employer, you should always ensure safety and good health of all your workers as well as those who dine at your restaurant. This is essential to keep your business running in a hassle-free manner.

Elevated temperature is bad for the safety of food products too. If the temperature inside the kitchen is very high, it can lead to the growth of microorganisms, affecting a number of food items. If used, these food products may cause different types of food-borne illnesses in customers. If you plan to run your business smoothly and avoid penalties or even closure, you should always invest in a top quality commercial kitchen ventilation hood system, installed by experts.

Install Type II Condensate Hoods

When it comes to controlling elevated temperature and moisture in a commercial kitchen, you can take several essential steps. Taking some small steps such as turning off the kitchen equipment when not in use, not allowing liquids to boil and using localized fans in excessively hot areas will be of help. But one major step you can take to deal with the problem of extreme heat and moisture in the kitchen is the installation of a Type II Condensate Hood. 

At Hood Builder in Denver, CO, we specialize in the installation of high quality Type II Condensate Hoods. Our restaurant services including range hood installation, HVAC air balancing and hood repair are known for their highest standards and top quality among commercial restaurant owners.

What is a Type II Condensate Hood?

Referred to as Oven Hoods or Condensate Hoods, Type II Hoods are a special model designed to remove heat, moisture and odors. These vent hoods are not installed over grease-producing cooking appliances.

If you already have the commercial kitchen hood system installed, you can use the Type II hood as an add-on. This type of range hood is installed over non-grease producing appliances such as light-duty ovens, pasta cookers, toasters, hot dog cookers etc. As far as the local building codes are concerned, it is not always mandatory to use a Type II hood. But using these hoods, in addition to your main ventilation system, will help you keep the kitchen environment cool and comfortable. These hoods are basically used to improve ventilation in a confined kitchen.

Benefits of Type II Condensate Hoods

Once installed, Type II hoods will bring your kitchen a host of benefits, which in turn will make the overall restaurant environment better and more comfortable for visitors and diners. If you think your ventilation system needs improvement, you should definitely consider installing these vent hoods.

Given below are some of the key benefits that installation of Type II Condensate Hoods brings to a commercial restaurant kitchen.

Reduce Temperature

The main purpose of installing a Type II Hood is to control elevated temperature in a commercial kitchen. As soon as you install these hoods, you will see a comprehensive reduction in the amount of heat. 

Remove Moisture

Too much moisture is a common problem in many restaurants. To find out whether you have this problem, all you need to do is remove the exhaust fan cover and look in it. Due to an excessive amount of moisture, you will face a number of issues over time such as corrosion of cooking equipment and growth of mold. Too much moisture can also take a toll on the building itself.

One surefire way to get rid of all these issues is to remove excess moisture through the installation of Type II Condensate Hoods.

Decrease Load on Kitchen HVAC

The kitchen ventilation system operates for hours on end to keep the kitchen air quality good and fresh. The HVAC or the makeup air system takes a great deal of load to perform its function. If you plan to reduce this load, installing Type II Condensate Hoods is a great idea. In this way, you will not just reduce the load on the ventilation hood system but you will also extend its lifespan.

Prevent Mold Growth

If the environment in the kitchen remains extremely hot and humid, food products will not be safe. There are many food items that need to be stored at a certain temperature. If the temperature exceeds or there is too much moisture, it will increase the risks of mildew and mold growth. This will damage the food items and result in a wide range of illnesses through contaminated food.

To prevent the growth of mildew and mold, you should definitely keep the temperature and moisture in your kitchen under control.

Reduce Slip Hazards

Safety of kitchen workers is a top priority for every restaurant owner. Due to excess moisture, the floors of the kitchen also remain wet. When humidity goes out of control, it is not just the kitchen floor, but floors in the dining area also remain wet. Also, the floors do not dry fast after mopping. Such safety hazards are always the reason for slips and falls that are common in many kitchens.

Installation of Type II Condensate Hoods will help you bring the moisture and humidity in the commercial kitchen under control. 

As you can see, using Type II Condensate Hoods will help you get rid of several issues in the commercial kitchen. Maintain Proper Ventilation in Your Restaurant

It must be reiterated that the kind of environment you have in your kitchen will affect the environment of the entire restaurant. When you open a new restaurant or operate one, the first thing you should focus on is maintaining proper ventilation in the kitchen. Since a commercial kitchen generates a great deal of heat, steam and smoke on a constant basis, not paying serious attention to its ventilation will lead to a number of problems that will ultimately drive away customers. Think of Type II Condensate Hoods as an additional but highly efficient model that completes your commercial kitchen HVAC system. This is a surefire way of controlling excessive heat and moisture in the kitchen.

Talk to a Vent Hood Design Specialist

Commercial Kitchen Construction and Redesign: Three Different Approaches for Business Owners to Take

When it comes to commercial kitchen design and restaurant renovation, one of the most crucial things is to know and decide whether your entire business will need to shut down for the project to complete. Most commercial kitchen construction services will present you with three approaches. However, which approach will work best depends on the size and goals of a particular project.

Phased Construction: This approach refers to a process in which the redesign and construction of the commercial kitchen is carried out in multiple small phases rather than in a continuous manner. If you plan to have the minimum amount of disruption to your commercial operations, phased construction is the most suitable option to go for. Using this approach means there will be no requirement for complete shutdown of the restaurant and the commercial kitchen. Since some parts of the kitchen facility will remain in operation during the remodeling or redesigning work, you can still run your business on a day-to-day basis. 

Full Shutdown: Based on the specific needs of the remodel project, the restaurant general contracting company may want you to completely shut down your commercial operations. Though this approach requires a great deal of planning, the approach can reduce the timeframe for the project.

Temporary Commercial Kitchen: In many cases, the best idea would be to set up a temporary kitchen in order for the commercial operations to continue uninterruptedly. The short-term kitchen can be set up in any other area of the restaurant facility. In this way, you will not need to disrupt your commercial operations or shut down the operations completely. However, problems with the system do not occur just because of a faulty compressor. If any of the HVAC unit components fails to do its job, the entire system will be affected.

The main parts that a commercial heating, ventilation and air-conditioning system consists of are as follows: 

  • Air conditioner
  • Compressor
  • Condenser
  • Expansion valve
  • Air Handler
  • Chillers
  • Roof-top units
  • Duct work

Apart from these main elements, there are several other smaller components fitted and installed in the system. The evaporator coil and the blower are together known as air handlers. Each of these components is designed to perform a specific function and together ensure overall performance of the heating and ventilation system. In order to maintain peak efficiency, you should get inspections and maintenance done without any delay or negligence. Common Reasons Why HVAC Systems Lose Efficiency

If you are operating a less efficient HVAC system, you will face multiple issues. One of the major ones among them is high energy bills. If you find that the energy consumption of your machines has been going up for the last couple of years, you should definitely consider an HVAC inspection.

Here are some of the most common causes that can lead to a loss of efficiency of commercial HVAC machines.

Clogged Air Filters

The role of an air filter is to filter out dust and air-borne particles. In this way, the filters help the HVAC machine do its job properly. So, you should never underestimate the significance of these air filters.

As the air filters continue to do their job, they collect a lot of dust and dirt over time. Often, they get clogged after some time. Clogged or blocked air filters fail to do their job in a proper manner. As a result of too much dust, the air filters cannot adequately circulate air through the HVAC machines. If the dirty air filters are not cleaned, it becomes a reason for the equipment to lose efficiency. That is why it is crucial to not leave the air filters unchecked for a long time. Instead, you should check these parts and replace them in a timely manner.

Dirty Air Conditioner Coils

The air conditioning unit of an HVAC machine has two coils: the evaporator coil and the condenser coil. The former is located in the indoor unit whereas the latter is located in the outdoor unit. However, these coils work in collaboration with each other in order to deliver performance. The role of the evaporator coil is to absorb the heat from the indoor air of the restaurant kitchen. The condenser coil lets out the captured heat outdoors. As a result, the indoor air in the kitchen remains cool and comfortable. But these coils can gather dust and dirt over time and fail to do the job in a proper manner. If the coils fail to do their job, the heat exchange process gets affected and the entire system can fail working as a result.

Dirty air conditioner coils take away the overall efficiency of the HVAC machine. If you plan to avoid such problems, you should get in touch with an HVAC company such as Hood Builder in Denver, CO, and have technicians to service the equipment and clean the dirty coils to restor efficiency.

Dirty Furnace Burners

The function of furnace burners is to produce heat. For this, the burners first mix fuel with air and then ignite the mixture. If the furnace burners fail to do their job properly, the heating system in your facility will be affected.

Just like filters and coils can get dirty, the furnace burners too can collect dust and dirt over time. Dust-covered burners struggle to burn the fuel or ignite in an efficient manner. Whether or not your burners are functioning correctly can be determined by using some technical methods. During an HVAC inspection or maintenance, the technician will take a closer look at the burners and see if they are clean or not. If the burners are filled with dust and dirt, cleaning will be required. Once the burners have been cleaned and re-installed, efficiency will be restored.

It is not a good idea to clean the furnace burners yourself, as it can be risky. The best option is to seek the help of an HVAC company in or near your area for properly cleaning of these vital components.

Leaking Ductwork

The ducting or the ductwork is an important part of the HVAC machine. The function of these components is to circulate cooled or heated air throughout the restaurant building. Compared to many other elements, these ducts are more prone to wear and tear and damage through use over time. Particularly, the joints along these ducts often get damaged and holes are formed. This is how the components start to leak and affect the efficiency of the entire HVAC system. Even if all the other parts of the HVAC perform well, leaky ducts can take their toll.

If your equipment has become less efficient, leaking ductwork could be one of the reasons. In order to reclaim HVAC system efficiency, the ducts will need to be repaired and sealed by a trained technician. 

Dust Buildup in Motor

HVAC motors play a crucial role of operating the hood fans, move pumps and drive compressors. A heating and ventilation system is run by a number of different types of motors with various starting torque levels. All these motors require proper maintenance on a regular basis. 

Over time, dust and dirt buildup degrades the functioning of the HVAC motors. Normal wear and tear takes a toll on these components. As a result, the efficiency level of the entire system goes down. Routine cleaning and lubrication are required to keep all these motors in excellent condition. When you seek the help of professionals for HVAC service, they will closely review the motors to find out if there are any issues with any of its components. The technician will replace the worn out parts with new ones in order to reclaim maximum efficiency of HVAC units.

Aging HVAC Equipment 

Commercial HVAC systems are designed to control heat and temperature and provide a safe and comfortable working environment for the employees as well as the visitors to the facility. No matter what type of heating and air conditioning equipment you have, its performance will decrease over time, as it becomes old. There are various factors that can expedite or slow down the aging of the HVAC units. When you hire a contractor or restaurant construction services, you should first invest in a high quality HVAC system that is most ideal for your daily needs. 

At the same time, you should give each HVAC unit timely and proper maintenance to prevent early equipment aging. 

On an average, the lifespan of a furnace is 15-20 years whereas an air conditioning unit can last for up to 15 years. The lifespan of a heating and ventilation system depends on the type, model, local environmental conditions and the use of the machines on a day-to-day basis. Even after maintenance, old age will finally kick in and your equipment will become less efficient over time.

Of all the components that an HVAC system is composed of, some parts will last as long as the lifespan of the equipment while others will be prone to wear and tear. For example, mechanical or moving components will suffer wear and tear, subject to the condition of the lubricant. The refrigerant is one part that can last for a long time, probably throughout the life of the equipment. You should remain aware of all the key parts and components and understand what kind of maintenance your system needs to keep all parts in excellent condition. With timely management, you will be able to avoid many of the problems due to which your equipment can age faster. Just keep a close watch on the performance of the system.

It is always best to regularly monitor the performance of your HVAC systems so that you can maintain good equipment health.

Tips to Restore the Lost Efficiency of HVAC Machines

A custom preventative maintenance program is essential to keep your HVAC machines functioning with maximum effectiveness.

What is Air Balancing?

Air balancing is a key part of the HVAC maintenance process. But what exactly does it mean to air-balance an HVAC system?

In simple terms, HVAC balancing refers to the maintenance and repair of the heating, ventilation, and air-conditioning system in order to make sure the entire system evenly distributes conditioned air throughout a commercial property or facility. As a result of this, uneven temperatures inside the property come down. Whether you operate a hotel, restaurant, or cafeteria and have an HVAC system installed in the facility, things can go wrong or issues may arise. If you plan to maximize the operation efficiency of the system, you should work with specialists to test, adjust, and balance the heating, ventilation, and air conditioning system. The purpose of air-balancing HVAC is to improve airflow within the facility.

Once the air-balancing has been completed, you will start to see and experience all the benefits it has to offer. The frequency of the task depends on what kind of issues you are having with your HVAC system. Usually, the system needs to be balanced when it is first installed and set up. After that, it will be required when you face the problem of uneven temperature in your facility.

Causes of Imbalance in the HVAC System

The big question is: What leads to an unbalanced HVAC system? Of course, HVAC needs balancing when there is an imbalance. There are multiple causes of an imbalance in the HVAC system, but it can be found out by experts only after a detailed assessment of the specific problem.

Before the process of balancing the HVAC system can begin, professionals will conduct an evaluation to discover the exact issue that has caused the imbalance. Since this is a highly technical job, experts use a variety of equipment and tools to properly check all the ducts or vents that comprise the system. There are three things in particular that the technicians check. These include the pressure and speed of the airflow and the fluctuations in the temperature.

Poor Airflow

If you suffer from poor airflow and uneven temperature, it could happen due to a number of reasons. Many times, such an issue comes up simply because the ductwork was not properly installed. Setting up an HVAC system involves a number of crucial processes, which should be completed with accuracy. If you work with inexperienced or novice technicians, they may install ducts and vents that are not the ideal size for the facility or building. In that case, the airflow and the air quality as a result will be affected. Another common cause of an imbalance in the HVAC system is worn-out or damaged ducts and vents. Filters of the wrong size or thickness can also be the cause of an unbalanced HVAC system.

To find out more about the causes of an unbalanced HVAC system, you should reach out to one of our experts at Hood Builder in Denver, CO. We specialize in air flow balancing, air duct balancing, AC balancing, and the installation, repair, and maintenance of all kinds of commercial HVAC systems.

Key Signs of Unbalanced HVAC Systems

When an HVAC system loses its balance, you will notice many signs or symptoms to know about the issue. For the heating ventilation and air-conditioning system to work with full efficiency, balanced air is a prerequisite. Any kind of imbalance will change the air quality and the temperature.

How Does Commercial Kitchen Ventilation Impact Customer Satisfaction?

Commercial kitchen ventilation plays a big role in a restaurant’s indoor air quality, temperature, smoke and odor management, air circulation, noise level, and overall ambiance of the place. Therefore, it directly affects the health and comfort of customers and staff.

First, we are going to discuss factors that contribute to a restaurant’s air quality to help owners discover the source of the problem. Then, we will recommend some effective ways that can improve a restaurant’s indoor atmosphere and air quality.

What Factors Affect Restaurant’s Indoor Air Quality?

For a healthy and comfortable environment in a restaurant, the following factors have the most significant effects.

  • Commercial Kitchen Ventilation Design and Efficiency

Inadequate restaurant ventilation systems or improper CKV design give rise to the problems below.

  • lower ventilation rates,
  • insufficient airflow,
  • poor odor control,
  • heat and humidity,
  • and improper pollutant removal.

All of these would mean poor indoor air quality and ambiance.

  • Exhaust Hoods

Insufficient exhaust hoods and filters cannot capture and remove grease and cooking-related pollutants and contaminants.

  • Layout of the Restaurant

How different components of a restaurant are organized, like restroom placement, seating arrangements, kitchen placement, and design, can have a positive or negative impact on the air circulation, airflow, and distribution of pollutants and odor.

  • Volatile Organic Compounds (VOCs)

Volatile Organic Compounds and other indoor pollutants, such as dust, allergens, and mold spores, reduce the air quality. VOCs are released from 

  • cleaning agents and detergents,
  • some chemicals and solvents,
  • some building materials and furnishings, like flooring oil-based finishes, paints, adhesives, and furniture upholstery.

Sometimes, the polluted outdoor air enters the restaurant through the windows, doors, etc. This is especially a problem for places near high-traffic streets, construction sites, and industrial areas.

These pollutants not only compromise the air quality but also may lead to health issues, particularly for sensitive groups.

  • Cooking Equipment Quality

The stoves, ovens, fryers, and other cooking equipment all have an effect on the air quality by the pollutants they release into the air.

Besides, the cooking methods, like open-flame cooking, frying, grilling, etc., are also important. Some cooking methods release more smoke, grease particles, and fumes into the air affecting its quality.

  • Cleaning and Maintenance

If there is no regular plan for proper maintenance and cleaning of the cooking equipment, ventilation hood, filters, and the whole place, contaminants and grease will build up leading to odorous and polluted air.

In addition, the chemicals, like disinfectants and detergents, used to clean the equipment and the place might have strong odors and introduce VOCs into the air.

  • Occupancy Level and Ventilation Rates

Each space has enough capacity for a certain number of people without causing humidity and airlessness. While it is necessary to consider the size of the place, ventilation rates should also be adjusted based on the number of people present in the restaurant. Higher levels of occupancy require higher ventilation rates.

  • Smoking Policy

Obviously, if smoking is allowed in indoor spaces, there is a significant decrease in the air quality due to the release of harmful chemicals and smoke.

To sum up, the quality and arrangement of the equipment, maintenance and cleaning activities, layout and organization of the restaurant, and some other factors determine the quality of the indoor air and ventilation. Restaurant owners should address any issues related to the factors above and take effective measures to enhance the dining experience for the customers.

Effective Ways to Improve the Ventilation and Air Quality in a Restaurant

Here are some strategies to ensure a pleasant dining atmosphere for customers, and a safe workplace for staff.

  • Investing in Quality HVAC Systems

The heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) system is essential in an essential part of any commercial kitchen ventilation. A high-quality HVAC controls the temperature efficiently, provides air filtration and fresh air (makeup air units), and promotes air ventilation and pressure relationships between different areas.

Therefore, an HVAC system improves indoor air quality by reducing pollutants and odors, and managing the temperature and airflow. Besides, maintaining the pressure is necessary in places like commercial kitchens to prevent depressurization which can lead to the accumulation of pollutants and toxic gases, such as carbon monoxide, in the air inside.

So, look out for any damage or malfunction related to the HVAC system and hire HVAC professionals to help you with its upkeep and upgrades.

  • Changing the Layout to Optimize Cross-Ventilation

Proper airflow is vital for ventilation and the layout has a significant impact on it. The doors, windows, and vents should be placed strategically as well as the kitchen and the restrooms.

Cross-ventilation means the fresh air enters the place while the stale air exits. And, in a restaurant remodeling the positions of walls, dining space, kitchen, door, windows, ventilation pathways (placement of vents, grills, and registers), etc., are changed to facilitate natural cross-ventilation and air circulation.

Additionally, during remodeling, owners can opt for incorporating smart ventilation systems that manage the airflow, ventilation rates, and temperature automatically based on parameters such as outdoor air quality, occupancy levels, etc.

  • Installing Well-Designed Exhaust Systems and Ventilation Fans

Placing powerful and high-quality exhaust hoods above cooking equipment ensures the proper removal of fumes, odors, airborne particles, and smoke. The filters and fans should be maintained and cleaned regularly to function effectively.

In addition to exhaust systems, installing ventilation fans strategically in the dining area prevents air stagnation.

Besides, determining the proper size and positioning of the exhaust hoods and ventilation fans requires experience. So, consulting with an expert can go a long way.

  • Utilizing Air Purification Technology

Air purifiers can be integrated into the HVAC systems or placed independently in the dining area to improve indoor air quality by removing pollutants and allergens. These devices include HEPA filters that effectively reduce airborne particles and create a healthier environment.

  • Regular Maintenance and Cleaning

Both the restaurant equipment and the place need proper scheduled cleaning and keeping up. Professional restaurant hood vent cleaning, exhaust hood filter replacement, and maintaining and cleaning ductwork and fans need to be taken seriously.

Staff must be trained on how to use the equipment appropriately. Also, they should keep an eye open for any ventilation-related issues and report them as soon as possible.

In addition, as chemicals and detergents can release contaminants and odors into the air, they should be stored in a specific place away from the kitchen and the dining area. Also, proper ventilation is necessary while using cleaning agents.

  • Monitoring Ventilation Systems

There are smart monitoring systems available nowadays that help restaurant managers assess the air quality and take action whenever needed. These devices can also be used to find out which part of the restaurant needs better ventilation.

In all, various measures can be taken to achieve a healthier and more inviting place. Which one of these strategies your restaurant needs to promote customer satisfaction is a matter that should be discussed with experts for a better outcome.

FAQs about Commercial Kitchen Ventilation System

As ventilation systems are crucial in a restaurant, there are always a lot of questions and concerns about them. Below, we try to answer some of these questions briefly.

What Are the Different Components of a Commercial Kitchen Ventilation System?

The ventilation system in a commercial kitchen should include the following.

  • Exhaust hood,
  • Ductwork,
  • Exhaust fans,
  • Makeup air unit,
  • Grease filters,
  • Fire suppression systems,
  • Air pollution control devices.

Why Is the Size of the Ventilation System Important?

Different components of the ventilation system should have proper sizing to be effective. For example, undersized exhaust hoods do not remove fumes, heat, odors, and pollutants properly. On the other hand, oversized exhaust hoods create excessive airflow which leads to negative pressure in the kitchen and waste of energy.

What Is Ductwork in a Commercial Kitchen Ventilation System?

The network of pipes or channels that transport the air and pollutants captured by the exhaust hoods to the outside is called ductwork. Proper size and design are necessary for appropriate functioning.

What Is a Makeup Air Unit?

Make-up air units are devices, like HVAC systems, that replace the stuffy air with fresh air, regulate temperature and humidity, maintain air and pressure balance, and enhance the operation of the exhaust hoods.

Can I Install a Ventilation System Myself?

The short answer is no. For a kitchen ventilation system to function properly, it should be designed, installed, and maintained appropriately. As ventilation is crucial for health and safety, it should not be taken lightly.

FAQ

Is hood important in the kitchen?

Heat and steam can make your kitchen uncomfortably warm and sticky without proper circulation. Installing a hood ventilation system helps capture moisture, preventing damage like cracked walls and ceilings. Neglecting to clean grease and residue can breed mold and bacteria. Stay vigilant, and keep your kitchen clean for a healthier cooking environment.

What is the purpose of an exhaust hood?

A kitchen hood, also called an exhaust hood or range hood, is a device with a mechanical fan suspended above the stove or cooktop. Its purpose is to remove airborne grease, combustion products, fumes, smoke, heat, and steam from the air by effectively evacuating and filtering them.

How effective is the kitchen hood?

As per findings from Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory (LBNL), the typical capture efficiency of standard hoods ranges from 30-40% on front burners and can reach as high as 90% on back burners.

How many types of main kitchen hoods are there?

There are different kitchen hood styles to choose from, including under-cabinet, wall-mount canopy, island canopy, hood liners, retractable downdraft, and microwave hood combinations. You can even opt for a custom hood that complements your cabinetry. Consider factors like kitchen layout, cooking habits, and personal taste when making your choice.

What type of hood do I need?

For optimal performance, choose a hood with a CFM rating of 900+ for your gas range. The size of your range determines the required CFM. If your range is against a wall, consider a wall hood, under-cabinet hood, or range hood insert. For a range on a kitchen island, use an island hood.

What are the different types of hoods in the industry?

There are three main types of hoods: Enclosing hoods, Receiving hoods, and Capturing hoods.

What is a professional hood?

Commercial-grade residential hoods, known as professional range hoods, are designed to fit perfectly over even the largest ranges. They effectively eliminate unwanted moisture, odors, smoke, and fine particles, ensuring your kitchen remains fresh and clean.

What is a standard height hood?

When determining the optimal range hood height, consider factors like the type of range hood, cooktop, and kitchen layout. For electric cooktops, install the range hood around 20-24 inches above the heat source. Gas cooktops require a range hood positioned around 24-30 inches above the stove. These considerations ensure effective ventilation and a comfortable cooking environment.

The impact of a kitchen ventilation hood on a fire hazard is underestimated when a fire hazard is mentioned. Most people think of sprinklers, extinguishers, and other tools to counter a fire threat. The reality of the situation is different, and kitchen hood can at least affect how often we have to deal with fires. 

Like many other incidents and disasters, a fire can be prevented and managed long before a disaster. Poor ventilation, grease build-up, lack of maintenance, and many other factors add to the possibility of a fire hazard. 

We will try to discuss the effect of ventilation and kitchen hoods on preventing a fire, as well as the impact they have during a fire. We will also discuss some tips on ensuring you get the most out of your ventilation system. 

We can provide help in a variety of restaurant services including ventilation in Colorado, don’t hesitate to call 303-777-7720 for a free quote

Get to Know the Labels

Before we get to the effect of a range hood and kitchen stove hood on a fire, first we briefly mention the different ways a fire could erupt. Aside from common sense, there are many sources provided by the NFPA, that can help us identify and prevent danger. 

Understanding the NFPA diamond, also called National Fire Protection Association 704, gives us a lot of edge when dealing with fire and its prevention. The labels give information about the different materials you might have in your kitchen and how dangerous they can be. 

You don’t need to memorize the exact number of National Fire Protection Association Labels, for every single chemical. Labeling the chemicals and the solutions you use in your kitchen is enough. It is just a precaution so you’d know what to keep away from fire. 

What Helps You Prevent Fire?

Let’s start simple. Take a look around the kitchen and check your cookers. Grease only helps to spread and increase the intensity of a fire. What sparks it though? Well, a spark of course! After working for long hours every day, you might get so tangled up in the work that you forget regular safety checks. 

The grease build-up is the nightmare of every chef, restaurant owner, health inspector, and especially the fire marshal. Let's just say it doesn’t really “help” in preventing a fire hazard. Naturally, neglecting the cleaning puts your kitchen at risk of many incidents, including fire. 

Check the Back!

Don’t limit the regular maintenance and checking to what you see. Try to check all the connections to the gas pipes and make sure they are in top shape since even a small leak can turn into a disaster. A proper ventilation system might help with the smell but it won’t solve the issue. 

Don’t Forget the Electricity 

A fire hazard might be misleading in its name.  It reminds us of gas, oil, or smoke. The reality is that the source of many fires can be traced to bad or old wiring and electrical equipment. This is why you should always put devices and wiring maintenance in your schedule.

Corrosion can be your worst enemy when it comes to the wiring and the equipment. The wires eventually start to heat up when exposed to electricity and might, in the best-case scenario, pop a circuit, or even cause a fire if sensitive material is nearby. 

Make Sure You’re Ready

Although we always try to minimize the chances of an incident from happening, it is always recommended to be prepared for when things get out of hand. Equipping your kitchen with proper fire alarm systems, smoke detectors, sprinklers, and fire suppression systems is a must for every owner. 

How does a kitchen hood help prevent fire?

Before a fire erupts, there are many signs and conditions to be met for a disaster to happen. One of which is poor ventilation of air. The grease particles floating in the air from all the cooking must land somewhere. 

Installation of a stove ventilation hood, in addition to the airflow of the kitchen, helps reduce the build-up of grease in your work area. This results in fewer accidents in your kitchen, however, cleaning the kitchen exhaust hood should also be a top priority to keep the equipment running smoothly. 

The ventilation hood is for many, sufficient for reducing the airborne grease, however, to help reduce the headache of cleaning the venting system and also the costs, some may turn to grease filters. This helps owners save time, money, and resources. 

This filtration of the air and cleaning of the airborne grease particles implicitly reduces the threat of fire by decreasing the build-up. However, you will need to tend to the stove exhaust hood as well, just to keep it clean and running smoothly for years to come. 

Keeping the Temperature Low

Aside from all the grease, fumes, carbon monoxide, and gasses that the kitchen ventilation hood vents out of your environment. One important aspect of its work is to bring down the temperature. This can help you cook easier and naturally, by decreasing the temperature, it lowers the chances of incidents related to heat from happening. 

Maintaining the Airflow

Keeping the air fresh has many benefits. Aside from venting out unpleasant smells and providing comfort while cooking. A stove hood can come in handy with smoke, gasses, and any other dangerous fume that needs to be ventilated. Remember that you need all the help you can get in a fire hazard.

If you are a restaurant owner in need of assistance in Colorado,  call 303-777-7720 for professional advice about the best equipment suited to your needs.

Does the variety matter?

Simply searching for a kitchen hood shows you hundreds of results for different types, models, shapes, and prices. This variety proves that there must be a difference between the different types of ventilation hoods. 

Most of the time these differences are related to the design that the customer has in mind. It is just a matter of taste and decoration. This of course affects the price but what about efficiency? Which model is best for our kitchen? Let’s look at the two main types of range hoods.

  • Ducted Range Hood

The most common type of kitchen ventilation hood and the one you probably use. Connected to a vent, the air flows through the stainless-steel baffles and filters and exits the building. External ventilation offers more safety in vacuuming out the smoke and dangerous fumes. 

Because of its efficiency, this is usually the top choice of most kitchens and restaurants. There is no need for constant cleaning of the filters and since a commercial kitchen is a busy place, a ducted range hood is simply a better option. 

  • Ductless Range Hood

Offering versatility in placement, the ductless range hood filters and recirculates the air back into the environment. This usually requires more fan power. This is not very efficient when it comes to saving energy and time, since the filters need constant cleaning to work properly.

The presence of carbon monoxide, formaldehyde (a chemical produced by heating oil), chemical cleaners, and other gasses and fumes inside a kitchen; especially a commercial kitchen where there is constant cooking, rules out the option of having a ductless range hood. 

There are always other factors such as the size, the power, the energy usage, etc. Which you need to consider. That is why it is important to look for the help of a professional when installing a kitchen hood. 

Ventilation in Crisis

An important aspect of any fire hazard, besides the flames, is the smoke. Although various extinguishers, sprinklers, and fire protection equipment can save you from fire, it is the kitchen fume hood and the ventilation system that save you from suffocation. 

Flames take a while to spread throughout the building. Smoke, however, doesn’t need more than 5 minutes to fill the entire place. What is important is to make sure you buy every second you can get, by providing a functional and efficient ventilation system.

Public safety is another important reason to install a decent ventilation system. The kitchen ventilation hood purifies the air from smoke, gas, and dangerous fumes, which gives you and your staff that extra edge to evacuate the building and minimize injuries and losses. 

This is the point that having a proper HVAC system comes in handy, as it can be a valuable tool in increasing the airflow and venting out smoke and gas.  Comfort is just one of the many qualities of having a functional HVAC system. Safety is the most important of those qualities. 

Installation Matters

As previously mentioned, the first line of defense for safe evacuation and fire prevention is equipping your kitchen with a functional and clean kitchen hood. Installation of a range hood vent can be overwhelming without the help of technicians and professionals. 

Efficiency is the key. The shortest possible ventilation path along with a wide range of cover, leads to faster ventilation. This is why we advise you to seek the help of a technician. Someone who can determine the best variation of kitchen ventilation hood, a/c system, and kitchen exhaust fan for the best result.
